inscribed:
x-54. Salonika.
A Gypsy girl, refugee maiden.
(See also Nos. x52-x53. 
Photo by Hine December, 1918

72.159.2114

(stamp)
Lewis W. Hine
Interpretive Photography
Hastins-on-Hudson, New York

makers.displaydate: 1874–1940; born Oshkosh, WI; died Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; active New York City, NY
makers.displaymaker: Lewis Wickes Hine, 1874–1940; born Oshkosh, WI; died Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; active New York City, NY

texts.textentryhtml: During the early twentieth century, the American sociologist and photographer Lewis Wickes Hine pioneered photography as a tool for social reform. This image, which he titled A Gypsy Girl, is part of a series in which Hines documented the experience of immigrants arriving on Ellis Island, New York. Hines used portraiture to show that the huddled masses of foreigners seeking sanctuary in the United States were made up of individuals and their families. By blending documentation with a sensitivity to the emotional state of the immigrants, Hines’s photographs not only captured the subjects’ individuality but also educated the public about the plight of the modern refugee.
texts.remarks: Gallery label text modified by curator to acknolwedge the use of the term "gypsy".

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1974", Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 33, no. 1 (1974): p. 37-47.
